data.title: chsh to powershell breaks the integrated terminal
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.11.2 (1.11.2)
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install [powershell](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellhttps://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell) on macOS. Add it to list of shells and set it as default terminal with `chsh`. (my current setup)
2. Run vscode and try to open the interactive terminal.

## Expected

Terminal opens and shows powershell

## Actual

Terminal crashes, because my settings now looks like this:

```
  // The path of the shell that the terminal uses on OS X.
  "terminal.integrated.shell.osx": "/usr/local/bin/powershell",

  // The command line arguments to use when on the OS X terminal.
  "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.osx": [
    "-l"
  ],
```

And `-l` is not a valid powershell flag.
PowerShell equivalent of it is `-noprofile`.

data.title: Provide auto-complete candidates for TypeScript string literal type when double quote is typed
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
```
type Color = "Red" | "Green" | "Blue";
let color: Color = " <-- No auto-complete until I press Ctrl+Space
```
When I type the double quote, the auto-complete popup should be showed. It should work like when I type the dot after an object name, the auto-complete popup is showed without Ctrl+Space.

data.title: Using WSL - How to use Bash for the launch configurations?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10  (Version 1703), with WSL enabled.

I asked [the question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/43480997/vscode-with-wsl-how-to-use-bash-for-the-launch-configurations) on StackOverflow, but without any answers, so I guess it's maybe not possible...

I use Visual Studio Code to develop a TypeScript Node application on Windows 10, with WSL enabled.

Thanks to [other][1] [threads][2], I'm almost able to run a VSCode task with Bash on Ubuntu on Windows.

But now I try to do the same with a *launch configuration*. How can I make a launch configuration to use the `node` executable *installed in WSL* instead of the one installed on Windows?

If I run this command directly in the integrated terminal, with Bash, it works :

    node src/start.js

But when I press "`[F5]`" and start a launch configuration that runs this same file, I get an error : "*Error: %1 is not a valid Win32 application*". This is because the `oracledb` library is used and has been compiled in Bash, not in Windows.

How can I make a launch configuration use Bash to run Node?

  [1]: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6579
  [2]: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24967

data.title: PSSession issues in console.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Powershell version: 5.0
Steps to Reproduce:

Note: This works in the ISE without issue. I only encounter the issue in VSCode.

1. `$creds = Get-Credential`
2.  `New-PSSession -computername 'computername' -credential $creds`
3. Verify session created, `get-pssession`
4. Attempt to enter session, `enter-pssession -id <Session ID>`

Results:

```
enter-pssession : Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
At line:1 char:1
+ enter-pssession -id 1
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Enter-PSSession], NullReferenceException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.NullReferenceException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.EnterPSSessionCommand

```

data.title: jsconfig.json rootDirs not working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: macOS 10.12.4
- OS Version: 1.11.2

My javascript files are importing modules using absolute paths such as

`import Formatter from 'app/utils/formatter';`

In 1.10, creating a `jsconfig.json` file will make go-to-definition work:

```
{
  "include": [
    "app/**/*",
    "config/**/*",
    "tests/**/*"
  ],
  "compilerOptions": {
    "baseUrl": ".",
    "rootDirs": [
      "app"
    ]
  }
}
```
However, after upgrading to 1.11.2, it no longer working. Holding CMD key and click the module, it pops up "no definition" message.

![screen shot 2017-04-19 at 10 27 46 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7303373/25193151/e67f13c0-24ea-11e7-9579-28fd163c34ed.png)

data.title: command not found after opening settings.json (vscodeVim/Vim extension)
data.body:
Posting issue here from https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1527, as the maintainer suggested this was a VSCode issue:

> This looks more like a vscode issue... I have noticed sometimes the cursor does not update correctly in the settings window only, but besides that have not seen anything like this @rebornix


--------

### What did you do?
opened VS Code, then opened settings and attempted to type in my settings.

### What did you expect to happen?

To be able to type as I would in any other file with the vim extension enabled.

### What happened instead?

In some cases, I get the following:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1024544/25153883/1fd26e9a-2443-11e7-9a92-adc58df74b48.png)

Multiple "command not founds"

In other cases (maybe where I have multiple windows for vscode open), I get no error messages and am unable to input data. Attached gif:

![screenflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1024544/25154190/779728fe-2444-11e7-97e2-eb1fe1f66d3d.gif)


Then I tried to go to other files to edit and continued to get the same errors until I restarted Code. 


### Technical details:

* VSCode Version: 1.11.2
* VsCodeVim Version: *0.6.16*
* OS: OSX El Capitan 10.11.6

data.title: Should I start working on a PR? (Intellisense/Quick info)
data.body:
VSCODE version: Version 1.11.2 (1.11.2)

There are great quick info/intellisense on some methods, like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8936090/25190326/2a01cdb8-252c-11e7-90a6-e46bd3af839a.png)

but others like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8936090/25190359/43bb60f2-252c-11e7-87e0-0f68c576bb4c.png)

I think it's very important to always have **one or two phrases to remind** us what do the property, method etc. really does. Because sometimes we forget that tiny difference that will avoid a bug or we just don't know what something does.

And it really saves time to have it flashed in a split second.

In lib.es6.d.ts there are about a couple hundred **important non-commented** items like these:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8936090/25191021/7090a77a-252e-11e7-909f-44db7f1bbd23.png)


If no one is planning on doing that soon, I'll do it myself and PR it. Also this'd be my first PR to a big project.

So: is anyone working on this? **Am I ok to start working on this without doubling efforts or wasting my time?**

When viewing invisible characters (editor.renderWhitespace), I would like the character/glyph used for tabs to extend across the full width of the tab (N spaces / to the next tab stop). Sublime Text 3 uses what looks like an emdash(?) or essentially a line than runs to the next tab stop. VSCode uses a single character width arrow. 

In descending order of preference:

  - an arrow that extends the full tab width (to the next tab stop)

data.title: Restore action to report negative startup times (insiders only)
data.body:
With 89cd0b7516a6870d4a6a2cd8e4b36286157462c6 code was introduced that loads the metrics too early (before the extension host is ready) resulting in caching bad metrics (containing NAN). The results is that the telemetry data is broken and that perf-command is broken

![screen shot 2017-04-19 at 18 10 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1794099/25190107/849ca230-252b-11e7-9489-8e56b88bd76b.png)

data.title: Use no lazy option to generate more cached data
data.body:
Since a while we use node/v8 cached data to speed up loading our code. Since v8 runs with `lazy` by default most parsing is deferred and therefore the cached data is incomplete as well. When starting with `nolazy` the parser won't take shortcuts and a *lot more* cached data will be produced. While that will slow down the very first startup (we generate cached data on client machines) it will improve performance on *every* subsequent startup by ~250ms. Numbers from my machine (spring 2015 mbp)

- no cached data (produce cached data), `lazy` => ~1250ms
- no cached data (produce cached data), `nolazy` => ~1450ms
- cached data, `lazy` => ~870ms
- cached data, `nolazy` => ~590ms

data.title: Remote debugging with different port numbers
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10

Steps to Reproduce:

I have a Vagrant VM which is running a node (v7.7.3) app. I ssh into the VM and run the node script with `--inspect=0.0.0.0:9229` to allow the inspector to bind on all interfaces. If I use the Chrome link that Node shows when it starts (changing the port to the mapped port and `localhost`) Chrome will correctly inspect the code and let me set breakpoints etc.

Disconnecting the Chrome inspect and then attempting to attach in VSCode results in this message in the Debug console:

> Debugging with inspector protocol because it was detected.

And then it immediately exits (i.e. no longer debugging).

If I leave Chrome connected and attempt to attach in VSCode I get an error message stating that it can't connect - there might be a Chrome connection (which is correct).

I don't get any other output stating why the attach might have disconnected. I've tried running from the cli with `--verbose` and it doesn't show any additional output.

This is the attach config from launch.json:

		{
			"type": "node",
			"request": "attach",
			"name": "Core Attach",
			"outFiles": [
				"${workspaceRoot}/dist/**/*.js"
			],
			"port": 19229,
			"address": "localhost",
			"localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
			"remoteRoot": "/core",
			"sourceMaps": true
		}

It might possibly be related to #22761, but that seems to say that it does attach okay, where as mine appears to attach for a moment and then immediately exit with no error given.

data.title: Extension "Cannot find module" in production (while does find in development)
data.body:
Hi, 
I made an extension, everything is fine.

I added [**`universal-analytics`**](https://github.com/peaksandpies/universal-analytics), which also works fine while extension is running in debug mode.
But I **don't receive any data from the live extension**.

VSCode: 1.11.2
OS: OSX El Capitan 10.11.6
Extensions: `ms-vscode.csharp` 1.8.1, `eppz.eppz-code` 1.1.21

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Google Analytics property.
2. Fork extension from [**`eppz/VSCode.Extension.eppz_Code`**](https://github.com/eppz/VSCode.Extension.eppz_Code)
3. Replace property ID in [**`Analytics.ts`**](https://github.com/eppz/VSCode.Extension.eppz_Code/blob/master/src/Analytics.ts#L29)
4. See it working (Real-Time).
5. The very same code released on marketplace not sending any data.

Is there **any permission** perhaps I should set to the extension?
What **other analytics** / telemetry solutions you suggest for extensions?

data.title: Code folding not working
Allow to change settings from Extensions editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>P</kbd> obviously doesn't help. But <kbd>⌘</kbd>+<kbd>⇧</kbd>+<kbd>P</kbd> doesn't help either. I try with different combinations of words but nothing.

Extensions mention things like:

> Disable active indentation guides for JavaScript files
> Set guides.active.enabled.javascript to false

Yes! Let's do it. But, where?

I'd imagine the gear icon that appears on each extension, the **universal symbol for settings** would get me there:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8936090/25179161/f49f34ee-2508-11e7-8303-9fb738dfadab.png)

Nope.

First page of googling "vscode change extension settings" and a couple of combinations, nothing. Except how to author my own extension (without mentioning the settings part).

Since the particular extension I want to customize is called "guides" and one setting offered by its doc is "guides.indent.backgrounds" I want to believe the first part is its own namespace. So I assume I put it in the same file with the vscode settings?

I don't know if I'm right but if I am, why do I have to "deduce" it? Why is all this part contradictory and not explained?

data.title: code_helper hangs and makes vscode unresponsive
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

code_helper hangs in background and makes vscode unresponsive. It has to be restarted with hard kill. This is randomly caused by indenting code using one of the vim plugins. In this case javascript.
The code_helper is hogging the CPU. Killing it doesn't bring back the responsiveness in the gui.

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: OSX El capitan 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. install plugin Vim emulation for visual studio (vscodevim) 0.6.16
2. Indent some lines marking them with shift-v-down then shift-= to indent.
